title: 115_s2195
content: The "Judicial Transparency and Ethics Enhancement Act of 2017" establishes an Inspector General for the Judicial Branch under Part III of title 28, United States Code. The "Judicial Transparency and Ethics Enhancement Act of 2017" establishes the Office of Inspector General for the Judicial Branch. The Inspector General is appointed by the Chief Justice of the United States for a 4-year term, with the possibility of reappointment for additional terms, and can be removed from office. The Inspector General for the Judicial Branch can be removed by the Chief Justice of the United States, who must provide reasons for the removal to Congress. The Office's duties include conducting investigations of misconduct in the judicial branch, including the Supreme Court, supervising audits and investigations, detecting waste, fraud, and abuse, and recommending changes in laws or regulations governing the judicial branch. The Inspector General for the Judicial Branch has the power to make investigations, obtain information from various agencies, and require witnesses to testify or produce documents. The Inspector General for the Judicial Branch has the authority to enforce subpoenas, administer oaths, employ officers and employees, obtain services, and enter into contracts for audits and studies as needed. Additionally, the Inspector General is limited in commencing investigations until certain conditions are met and is restricted from investigating matters directly related to judicial decisions or disciplining judges. The Inspector General for the Judicial Branch has the authority to enforce subpoenas, administer oaths, and report to the Chief Justice and Congress on activities. Reports may contain sensitive information and violations of Federal law must be promptly reported to the Attorney General. Whistleblower protection is provided for officers, employees, agents, and contractors. No officer, employee, agent, contractor, or subcontractor in the judicial branch may discriminate against an employee for providing information on violations of Federal law or misconduct. Injured employees can seek relief through civil action. Inspector General for the judicial branch is established.
